Award.AwardTitle: Quantum Groups, Quantum Symmetries, and Non-Commutative Geometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
Noncommutative geometry is a field of pure mathematics that traces its origins to problems in mathematical physics motivated by the discovery of quantum phenomena. The typical mathematical framework in which geometric entities (such as the 4-dimensional space-time that underlies the general theory of relativity) can be studied algebraically needs to be enlarged and generalized if it is to be reconciled with quantum phenomena. In the resulting setup, the symmetries of a physical system (in the sense of structure-preserving transformations) sometimes need to be discarded and replaced with new and more exotic notions of symmetry. The mathematical embodiment of these exotic symmetries are known as "quantum groups," and they are the main focus of this project. Much of what can be taken for granted in the context of "plain" geometry and actions of ordinary transformations on ordinary spaces becomes problematic in the noncommutative setting. This research project aims to shed light on a number of these problems, in a range of subfields within the larger realm of noncommutative geometry.

This project investigates several aspects of noncommutative geometry that revolve around the notion of quantum symmetry. This involves studying quantum groups, their representation theory, and their actions on algebraic and geometric structures, as well as attendant problems in non-commutative algebraic geometry. One goal is to further understand the phenomenon of quantum rigidity, whereby certain structures admit no truly quantum symmetries. What this means is that whenever a sufficiently well-behaved Hopf algebra (which is the algebraic embodiment of a quantum group) coacts in a structure-preserving manner, the coaction factors through one by the function algebra on an ordinary group. Many special cases of this are known (integral affine algebraic varieties, certain smooth non-commutative projective algebraic varieties, compact connected smooth manifolds, certain classes of metric spaces, etc.), but the general phenomenon is poorly understood. Another goal is to attempt to transport tools and concepts specific to discrete or reductive algebraic groups (such as Borel subgroups, maximal tori, weight systems, compactifications, residual finiteness, linearity) over to quantum groups in order to further elucidate their structure and representation theory. Finally, symmetry considerations allow for the construction of new examples of smooth noncommutative projective schemes that in some sense behave generically within the moduli spaces that classify such schemes. The representation theory of the corresponding algebras would then shed light into the nature of these moduli spaces that are at the moment not well understood.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project the present report refers to is a continuation of awards DMS-1565226 and DMS-1801011, both titled 'Quantum Groups, Quantum Symmetries, and Non-Commutative Geometry', and hence all projects are properly regarded as a coherent whole. They aimed to study a wide array of problems falling under the broad scope of non-commutative geometry; this is an area of mathematics concerned with abstract algebraic and/or geometric structures informed in various ways by insights deriving from mathematical physics, with a focus on quantum phenomena. The momentous discovery at the turn of the 20th century that certain pairs of physically-observable properties of a system (e.g. position and momentum) cannot be measured simultaneously with arbitrary precision (even in principle!) manifests mathematically as the non-commutativity of a pair of operations on the system; this is the origin of the term 'non-commutative geometry'.

Given that this was a pure-mathematics proposal, the outcomes consist mainly of academic publications in specialized journals along with conference/seminar/workshop presentations publicizing that research. Many of the proposed problems were resolved successfully, resulting in a relatively rich supply of such publications together with the ensuing research-communication activity; these outcomes are all listed in more detailed fashion in accompanying annual reports.

Various flavors of non-commutative geometry are of interest in different corners of mathematics: "pure" algebra, algebraic geometry, mathematical analysis, differential geometry, etc. In view of this, one explicitly-stated goal of the original proposal was to cut across specialized fields of mathematics by attacking thematically-varied problems with broad appeal. That this goal has been achieved is evidenced by the large number of collaborators on projects relevant to the proposal: over 30, affiliated with a large number of institutions across the world. This attests to the richness of the problem domain under consideration and plants the seeds for future projects and, one hopes, fruitful joint pursuits along different but related directions. It is the PI's belief that the momentum generated by vigorous international collaboration, spread over diverse domains of expertise, will be conducive to

- generating novel ideas;

- uncovering new areas and/or directions of investigation;

- deploying a rich toolkit to resolving the problems being considered.

To summarize, the project has

- facilitated conducting and communicating research of potential interest to specialists in diverse areas of mathematics;

- sparked long-running international collaborations with fellow researchers based at numerous institutions;

- provided an ample supply of suggestions for additional future study (some of it the subject of newer NSF funding), and, additionally,

- greatly contributed to the PI's professional development by providing the above-mentioned opportunities to conduct and present research and interact with colleagues.
